section.title: Grammatical function tags
section.p: Our syntactic tags (grammatical function tags like @SUBJ, @OBJ, etc.) are based upon a compromise between the Sámi grammatical tradition and the conventions used within constraint grammar (CG), e.g. as found in visl project for interactive syntax learning. The main difference between the two is that CG is a linear system, where tags are given to wordforms, and not to phrases. Thus, in a sentence like the Sámi equivalent of Peter's dog barks only the word dog will get the tag @SUBJ. The word Peter's gets the tag @GN>, or "genitive modifying a noun to its right". It is then up to the reader (or to further computer processing) to interpret the combination of @GN> and @SUBJ as a phrase.

Note that all syntactic tags are identified by an initial @ symbol, to distinguish them from morphological tags, which do not have such a prefix. In the analysis, the syntactic tags are printed at the end of the tag string.

section.title: A systematic grouping of the tags
section.p: The Sámi disambiguation file sme-dis.rle adds syntactic tags to each cohort.

section.title: The verb tags
section.p: These tags are self-explanatory: there are finite and infinite main and auxiliary verbs.

section.title: The major function tags
section.p: The four main functions for subject, object and their predicatives are obvious.
The @SUBJ-QH is a tag for quantifier heads of nouns. This goes both for singular and plural quantifiers.
The @-FSUBJ is a tag for subjects of infinite verbs, like mu in Diet dáhpáhuvai mu dieđikeahttá. The tag hits rarely, e.g. not once in our corpus of bureaucratic texts.

section.title: The adverbial tags
section.p: The @ADV-A tag is for adverbs modifying adjectives, and the @ADV-ADV tag is for adverbs modifying adverbs.
The @ADVL tag marks adverbials (many, but not all of the adverbials are adverbs)
Discussion: We should consider unifying some of the adverbial tags. Against unification speak the possibilities of using the fine-grained distinctions in the disambiguation.

section.title: The NP-internal modifiers
section.p: The @NUM-PRON tag is for numerals modifying pronouns to their left, like in Mii golmmas finaimet máná geahčen.
There are 10 tags for constituents modifying a noun from the left, selecting, adjective, Actio, Determiner, Genitive noun or pronoun, proper noun, participle, pronoun or quantifier.
Discussion: The quantifier modifying N is for the oblique cases like Son lea vihtta jagi boaris.
There are 5 tags for constituents modifying from the right, quantifiers (@QN<) and pronouns (@PronN<) modifying nouns, and nouns modifying pronouns (@NPron<) and quantifiers (@NQ<).
